title: Grade 12 - Contemporary Indigenous Issues and Perspectives in a Global Context NDW4M (2019)
subject: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit Studies

document.title: Grade 12 - Contemporary Indigenous Issues and Perspectives in a Global Context NDW4M (2019)

F51C6523226D45949CC7E258617D91F9.description: describe some ways in which peoples around the world have used traditional Indigenous knowledge to address governance issues

73AD230DCA4D4CBA9827C179A4B4E72B.description: analyse the impact of technological advances on Indigenous peoples in Canada and around the world

B7F74CDB3B4C4ACE86C2D479B60817DE.description: describe some ways in which Indigenous individuals and organizations in Canada have engaged in national and international forums and with non-governmental and/or intergovernmental organizations to forward political and legal issues

17B0179D401947C198572417BEF2A285.description: assess the strengths and weaknesses of international agreements aimed at protecting various categories of rights and freedoms that are of importance to Indigenous peoples in Canada and around the world

2B1C6558424649E4AA69DA9F90075E73.description: explain how some factors that affect the self-determination, sovereignty, and self-governance of Indigenous peoples in Canada also affect Indigenous peoples in other parts of the world

5DEAA85A37E64F45B9EC51729DA0E582.description: The International Context: demonstrate an understanding of the commonality of issues affecting Indigenous peoples both in Canada and around the world, with particular reference to self-determination, sovereignty, self-governance, human rights, and traditional Indigenous knowledge

24F8290F4EF04AF2B14525266022F723.description: describe ways in which Indigenous governments are developing local governance capacity as a means to provide effective and accountable government for their members, with particular reference to customary law or tradition

8F6A3638BE84470093A7E247EFE13AD1.description: explain the fiscal relationship between the federal government and Indigenous governments in Canada, including the “own-source revenue” policy, and the implications of this relationship for self-determination, sovereignty, and self-governance

7231428638C44F1A825DEE23F381991C.description: analyse some of the calls to action in the Final Report of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada

808C6DFCB195472CB95C2685F1D37809.description: describe strategies that various individuals and groups

01ED658A1DCA4680B3D807ACA1AE5967.description: identify some of the responsibilities that are associated with Indigenous self-determination, sovereignty, and self-governance (e.g., providing leadership, developing membership codes, visioning, risk management, strategic planning, community planning, community consultation, developing dispute-resolution measures and law-making procedures, financial management, human resource management, administration, external relations), and explain some of the ways in which First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities are meeting or seeking to meet these responsibilities

3FAEDDCA9FBA4B718A2F186A4DDF7A2F.description: Responsibilities and Self-Determination: identify responsibilities associated with the goals of self-determination, sovereignty, self-governance, and reconciliation, and analyse strategies and practices that First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities have used and are using to pursue these goals

0B471DB01BEA419D8F3A6AA230F049D1.description: describe the legal significance of particular rights sought by advocates of Indigenous sovereignty and self-governance

FE30191C1214412AA716B32CC89D1FB0.description: describe the main principles of Indigenous sovereignty, self-governance, law, and leadership

1A275376A0E6479CB9D317A8088E3CED.description: describe some precontact systems of self-governance among First Nations and various traditional teachings and protocols regarding self-governance and leadership in First Nations and Inuit cultures

9AAD591F3416433EB224EC452BC0AFAD.description: Principles of Sovereignty and Self-Governance: demonstrate an understanding of key principles of and teachings and protocols related to Indigenous sovereignty and self-governance, including an understanding of the diversity of such teachings/protocols

46DF5970889D4C8C8B5317C68CC7E86C.description: assess the strengths and weaknesses of current laws and agreements in terms of their ability to protect the rights of First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities in the face of human activities that affect the natural environment

73DBCBB6179C4F988557C61072050412.description: analyse different types of land-based disputes that have existed and/or continue to exist between First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities and federal, provincial, and/or territorial governments

BD7B7A348B794926A4E183032BBCD1CF.description: describe perceptions of land and land use that are foundational to Indigenous peoples in Canada

E3C54823341B4E7DA7B154C453FC1CB8.description: Land and Self-Determination: analyse the relationship of Indigenous peoples to the land and how land-based issues are related to Indigenous rights, self-determination, sovereignty, and self-governance

165F2337DA86441991D6F9DFBC6EEBEC.description: explain how various First Nations, Métis, and/or Inuit political organizations

AA0B0B11ABB849669F1562A0F9D91B17.description: explain the Crown’s fiduciary obligation towards Indigenous peoples, with specific reference to Guerin v. Queen, 1984

47B456EC41EF42A791E176957CF94A63.description: explain the Supreme Court of Canada’s finding (in Haida Nation v. British Columbia, 2004, and Taku River Tlingit First Nation v. British Columbia, 2004) that the federal government has a duty to consult and accommodate Indigenous peoples, and analyse the impact of this finding on the relationship between Indigenous peoples and Canadian governments

D39E2C120EAA44E89945E16B2D61F2FC.description: analyse key factors, including specific policies

6D97E5B16D4940BB9DB7EAFF77CFF5AC.description: Changing Political Relations: analyse aspects of the relationship between Indigenous peoples and federal and provincial/territorial governments since the 1980s, including factors that have affected these relationships

478E13863FF54688834A9276F0EC49B3.description: explain how social attitudes, values, and/or trends have influenced laws and government policies, both in Canada and internationally, that have affected and/or continue to affect the lives of First Nations, Métis, and/or Inuit individuals and communities in Canada

30C63BAD27AB409B80A523663F0BAF61.description: assess how current and proposed legislation may affect the rights of First Nations, Métis, and/or Inuit individuals and communities in Canada

C6B4520FA7FE4A59A4BBF906F9C5E105.description: analyse laws and political policies since the 1970s that have affected First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities, with a particular focus on laws and policies that have attempted to address the legacy of domination by colonial, federal, and provincial/territorial governments

5ED6580FE8214DF89C5AFC9CE902C838.description: analyse differences between historical treaties and modern land claim agreements, with reference to process, spirit, and intent as well as the impact of these agreements on First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities in Canada

C1B59BF7FE8848A2AD8EB4998C6D5B5E.description: Law and Policy: analyse how various laws, policies, and agreements since the 1980s have affected First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities in Canada

E12666ECC4FC4268A477F32710E929D8.description: explain the role of the judiciary in interpreting and enforcing the Charter and other constitutional provisions in decisions that have affected First Nations, Métis, and/or Inuit individuals and communities in Canada

191CC13B30FE4D04848761E12C1FDB8E.description: identify some of the rights and freedoms protected by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (the Charter)

E7BB680B3975496FB3511272AFC55B16.description: assess the significance of section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982, including its ability to guarantee Aboriginal rights and accommodate the needs of diverse First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities

97665B0D0D9744BA8CBE1C3D624393A8.description: Constitutional/Charter Rights: demonstrate an understanding of the impact that the Constitution Act, 1982 and the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms have had on First Nations, Métis, and Inuit rights in Canada

9FCDB5486E3844968B9EF5AE08819DEE.description: assess various ways in which First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities in Canada have acted to protect treaty rights and/or land claim agreements since the 1980s

A26A3A8303A74F91B1EDAEB022A88B28.description: explain, with reference to some key decisions

1F4469ADC4464FC0840CC966A617A138.description: describe circumstances in which individual and/or group rights and freedoms of various Indigenous peoples in Canada have been threatened, limited, and/or violated since the 1980s

AC91968CD5CA4989AECA7EE5A88E5E1A.description: describe inherent First Nations, Métis, and Inuit rights in Canada and how they are connected to traditional territories and cultures

16EADFF8A774453EB0FE76C8915BE25C.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit Rights: demonstrate an understanding of First Nations, Métis, and Inuit rights in Canada and of various factors that affect them

EE154CEAA08642CC9484D42873DC849C.description: Support for and Challenges to Indigenous Rights

4464695887104805923F2DCE3A790EE8.description: describe some ways in which First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals, communities, and/or advocacy groups responded to and/or tried to influence relations with governments in Canada prior to 1980

8E91E3A83DAB48A5B3752A4C18F66C0D.description: describe some decisions of the judicial branch of the government that were related to Aboriginal rights and title prior to 1980

A660558D3F6B4E729D3E5333E7E88167.description: identify various factors that affected the political relationship between Indigenous peoples and colonial, federal, and/or provincial/territorial governments in Canada prior to 1980, and explain their impact

C29BDB4B74814B2D9EBEFA79C669470A.description: Political Relations: analyse relationships between Indigenous peoples and colonial, federal, and/or provincial/territorial governments in Canada prior to 1980

DC85EDC86420441296CAF504236C34A0.description: assess the impact that federal legislation in Canada had on First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities prior to the 1960s

0740425C317E458F87F3F158381EA05B.description: describe key federal legislation in Canada prior to the 1960s that was of relevance to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities, with reference to both its motivation and content

48F5F4D2060D4BBD96D689A58D124F53.description: explain the motivation for and impact on First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities of key pieces of colonial legislation, including the Royal Proclamation of 1763

45E80570A9A94993BDBC874A82109CF1.description: Legislation: describe historical legislation at the colonial and federal levels that has affected First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities in Canada, and assess its impact

15A470E5ED5F46CD8D5D580C77577844.description: explain the intent, scope, and processes associated with land claim agreements prior to 1982

8F3384279C254C21A4ABCB8AC05D2736.description: explain the force and scope of key historical treaties between First Nations and colonial/federal governments, with reference to both their legal and cultural implications

4143145F0744433286A66FDF6E0565BD.description: analyse the spirit and intent of, and processes involved in, key historical treaties between First Nations and colonial/federal governments in Canada

799CA4BF990A48538769EE548393D50E.description: identify the areas of Canada that are covered by historical treaties and land claim agreements that date from prior to 1980 between various Indigenous peoples and colonial, federal, and/or provincial/territorial governments

C1C5542683CE4EDD81AC38900BCC81DA.description: Treaties and Land Claim Agreements: demonstrate an understanding of the intent and scope of, and processes associated with, historical treaties and land claim agreements between Indigenous peoples and colonial, federal, and/or provincial/territorial governments in Canada prior to 1982

66484825D10640ED878B88BA82897CC9.description: identify various careers in which a background in First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and/or Indigenous law might be an asset

1D29F259C3044F59ADBE436BBD767A04.description: use the concepts of legal thinking when analysing current events relating to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada in order to enhance their understanding of these events and their role as informed citizens

5133EFC8F8284D8684E214B6DCE4FA4E.description: demonstrate in everyday contexts attributes, skills, and work habits developed through the study of First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada

C19D2BC7EBA44757BFFE6C8979E18CDF.description: describe several ways in which investigations related to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada can help them develop essential skills

650E45E4FD8344058D54D1CA8E4A3B4B.description: Developing Transferable Skills: apply in everyday contexts skills developed through the study of First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law, and identify various careers in which a background in these areas might be an asset

6748CB0D2E8A46AEA3D0CBB610D321A5.description: assess and use terminology appropriate to the audience and purpose when communicating the results of their investigations

D7995C27B150467D8EAA84CF269C30D6.description: communicate their ideas, arguments, and conclusions using various formats and styles, as appropriate for the audience and purpose

255A7C95802C4FC4B48797C5C43CD8D6.description: evaluate and synthesize their findings to formulate conclusions and/or make informed judgements or predictions about the issues, events, and/or developments they are investigating

95F0A3829D7F46B591E8933AE34CB098.description: use the concepts of legal thinking (i.e., legal significance, continuity and change, interrelationships, and legal perspective) when analysing, evaluating evidence about, and formulating conclusions and/or judgements regarding issues, events, and/or developments relating to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada

0CA1680F052849C3BFB22B71BE54C512.description: interpret and analyse evidence, data, and information relevant to their investigations, using a variety of tools, strategies, and approaches appropriate for inquiry in legal studies

D5EC4F722D3E46F38495FA680331E651.description: assess the accuracy and credibility of sources relevant to their investigations

BB56754C0B7A4C9A973D4B053F987E9B.description: select and organize relevant evidence, data, and information on issues, events, and/or developments relating to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada from a variety of primary and secondary sources, including Indigenous knowledge sources

7800926184AC4E969C7F58C61345E092.description: formulate different types of questions to guide investigations into current and historical issues relating to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada

A9D94AC21AE14894881B0DAFEBC03032.description: The Inquiry Process in Legal Studies: use the legal studies inquiry process and the concepts of legal thinking when investigating issues pertaining to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada

83C230BFD7D94035B3E25DE24E6225B1.description: The Legal Studies Inquiry Process and Skill Development

8CEEA02C80854BBBAAB4AF09CF14A7E9.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit Studies
